node.title: Pakistan, Stricken by Surging Inflation, Seeks an I.M.F. Lifeline
node.alt: “I am not making any profit these days,” Muhammad Nazir said from his shop in Sohawa, a town about 50 miles southeast of Pakistan’s capital, Islamabad.
node.description: Rising prices and a weakened currency are straining households, intensifying pressure on Prime Minister Imran Khan to find solutions.
node.content: ["Muhammad Nazir canceled his daughter\u2019s wedding. He parks his motorcycle at home and walks to his shop. Many of his shelves are empty because he can\u2019t afford to stock the same supply of candy, soft drinks and cookies that he once did.", "A growing number of his customers can\u2019t buy his snacks anyway. The global inflation wave has dealt a severe blow to Pakistan, a country of 220 million people already struggling with erratic growth and heavy government debt.", "As the cost of food and fuel eats up a larger share of meager incomes, people are putting pressure on the government of Prime Minister Imran Khan to do something.", "\u201cI am not making any profit these days,\u201d Mr. Nazir, 66, said from his shop in Sohawa, a town about 50 miles southeast of Pakistan\u2019s capital of Islamabad. \u201cStill, I come here every day, open the shop and wait for customers.\u201d", "Surging prices have imperiled President Biden\u2019s agenda in the United States and hit shoppers from Germany to Mexico to South Africa. But they are having a particularly nasty effect in Pakistan, a developing country already prone to political instability and heavily dependent on imports like fuel. The effect has been worsened by a sharp weakening of Pakistan\u2019s currency, the rupee, giving it less purchasing power internationally.", "While inflation is expected to ease as supply-chain bottlenecks unsnarl, Pakistan feels it can\u2019t wait. On Monday, the government announced that it had reached an agreement with the International Monetary Fund for the first $1 billion of what is expected to be a $6 billion rescue package.", "\u201cThe economy is the biggest threat that the government is in fact facing right now,\u201d said Khurram Husain, a business journalist in Karachi. \u201cThis is basically eroding the very basis of their public support.\u201d", "Protests organized by opposition parties have broken out across Pakistan in recent weeks, causing Mr. Khan\u2019s political allies to examine their loyalties. The Pakistan Muslim League-Q, or P.M.L.-Q, party, which is in coalition with Mr. Khan, said earlier this month that it was becoming difficult to remain part of the government.", "\u201cOur members of parliament are feeling a lot of pressure in their constituencies,\u201d said Moonis Elahi, Mr. Khan\u2019s minister for water resources and a member of P.M.L.-Q. \u201cSome even suggested leaving the alliance if the situation doesn\u2019t improve.\u201d", "Government officials have downplayed the recent surge in inflation, saying it is a global phenomenon. Mr. Khan has also blamed the foreign debt burden he inherited from the previous government.", "\u201cThe government spent the first year in stabilizing the economy but when it was close to stabilizing it, the country faced the biggest crisis in 100 years: the coronavirus epidemic,\u201d he said, adding \u201cno doubt the inflation is an issue.\u201d", "Officials also cite price comparisons of fuel costs with neighboring countries, like India, claiming that Pakistan is still better off. Pakistanis have seen standard gas prices jump 34 percent in the last six months, to about 146 rupees a liter.", "Pakistan has been rushing to tamp down inflation and get the money it needs to keep buying abroad. Last week, Pakistan\u2019s central bank sharply raised interest rates, a move that could help cool price increases but one that could crimp economic growth.", "Mr. Khan\u2019s government reached out to Saudi Arabia for a lifeline. The Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, pledged $4.2 billion in cash assistance. Members of his government are also chasing loans from China they say are needed to complete crucial power-sector projects that are part of the $62 billion China-Pakistan Economic Corridor.", "Pakistan\u2019s economy has been in and out of crisis since Mr. Khan, a former cricket star, came to power in 2018. But other periods of inflation were felt mainly by the rich, economists say. This bad turn is affecting everyone.", "Inflation surged 9.2 percent in October from the year before, according to government data. Food-price inflation is crushing Pakistan\u2019s poorest residents, who already normally spend more than half of their incomes on food. The cost of basic food items shot up earlier this month by 17 percent year over year, government data show. Pakistan\u2019s biggest food import is palm oil, which has jumped in price.", "In the United States, food prices have risen by 4.6 percent.", "In terms of energy, Pakistan imports about 80 percent of its oil and diesel and about 35 percent of its gasoline, according to Muzzammil Aslam, a spokesman for the finance ministry. The cost of electricity in Pakistan is already twice as much as in neighboring countries like India, China and Bangladesh.", "\u201cThe economy is not well,\u201d Mian Nasser Hyatt Maggo, the president of the Federation of Pakistan Chambers of Commerce & Industry, a Karachi-based industry group, said simply.", "Unemployment has risen sharply, too, particularly among college graduates in cities. The number of people falling into poverty is up.", "The problems have added urgency to Pakistan\u2019s drive to establish a $6 billion loan program with the I.M.F. Talks have gone on for weeks, stumbling over Pakistan\u2019s insistence that the governor of the central bank, which sets interest rates, report to Mr. Khan\u2019s government, and the I.M.F. insistence that the office remain autonomous. Pakistan was part of an I.M.F. program in 2019, but the program was suspended a year later when the I.M.F. said that Pakistan was not implementing its recommendations for structural reform.", "Even if the deal comes through, Pakistan\u2019s economic pain would not end immediately.", "Mr. Khan\u2019s government helped Pakistan weather pandemic lockdowns and other disruptions to business and trade with generous spending packages to industry. That drove up demand for imported factory parts, raw materials and other goods, pushing up Pakistan\u2019s trade deficit. That, in turn, puts pressure on the rupee to weaken, making imports more expensive.", "\u201cWe have a huge budgetary deficit and a huge trade deficit. The trade deficit over the last three months I haven\u2019t seen over the last 74 years in Pakistan,\u201d said Farrukh Saleem, an economic analyst in Islamabad.", "Mr. Saleem projected that Pakistan\u2019s imports would soon hit $72 billion, more than double the norm.", "A stamp of approval from the I.M.F. would make it easier for Pakistan to approach the World Bank and Asian Development Bank as well as capital markets where it could sell bonds.", "Mr. Khan\u2019s government has distributed cash to 20 million of Pakistan\u2019s poorest families and subsidized the cost of grains, legumes and cooking oil. If Pakistan finalizes an agreement with the I.M.F., it will have to tighten its purse strings.", "That will hurt Mr. Khan politically in places like Sohawa, where many people supported him in the last general election.", "\u201cImran Khan is a good person and is still liked by many, but his team is not performing,\u201d said Saleem Shahzad, a plumber who recently moved his 6-year-old son to a less expensive school.", "\u201cIt is incompetent,\u201d he said."]
